column65:
Cash and cash equivalents
Cash and cash equivalents comprise "Cash at bank and in hand" and "Current asset investments" as well as âCredit institutionsâ under liabilities and equity. "Current asset investments" consist of short-term securities with an insignificant risk of value changes that can readily be turned into cash.
column71: The Board of Directors and the Executive Board have today considered and adopted the Annual Report of JYSK Holding A/S for the financial year 1 September 2014 â 31 August 2015.
column72:
Report on the Consolidated Financial Statements and Parent Company Financial Statements
We have audited the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements of JYSK Holding A/S for the financial year 1 September 2014 to 31 August 2015, which comprise income statement, balance sheet, notes and accounting policies for both the Group and the Parent Company, as well as consolidated cash flow statement. The Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements are prepared in accordance with the Danish Financial Statements Act.
column73: Independent Auditorâs Report
column74:
JYSK Holding A/S is described by the following financial highlights

The ratios have been prepared in accordance with the definitions provided under accounting policies.
column75:
Basis of consolidation
The Consolidated Financial Statements comprise the Parent Company, JYSK Holding A/S, and subsidiaries in which the Parent Company directly or indirectly holds more than 50% of the votes or in which the Parent Company, through share ownership or otherwise, exercises control. Enterprises in which the Group holds between 20% and 50% of the votes and exercises significant influence but not control are classified as associates.
Elimination is made of intercompany income and expenses, shareholdings, dividends and accounts as well as of realised and unrealised profits and losses on transactions between the consolidated enterprises.
The financial statements applied for the Groupâs Annual Report have been prepared in accordance with the accounting policies of the Group.
column76:
Non-controlling interests
On statement of group results and group equity, the shares of results and equity of subsidiaries attributable to minority interests are recognised as separate items in the income statement and the balance sheet.
column77: The Annual Report of JYSK Holding A/S for the financial year 1 September 2014 to 31 August 2015 has been prepared in accordance with the provisions of the Danish Financial Statements Act applying to large enterprises of reporting class C.
column78:
Segment reporting
In accordance with section 96(1) of the Danish Financial Statements Act, disclosures on revenue broken down by business segments are not provided as the Companyâs Executive Board and Board of Directors assess that such disclosures would be very detrimental to the Company.
column80:
Managementâs Review
Main activity
The activity of the Parent Company comprises operation of real property, investments in subsidiaries and associates as well as current asset investments.
The Groupâs main activities are carried out in subsidiaries dealing in retail trade through the retail chain JYSK selling everything for the bed room, bath room, other rooms, the window and the patio. The activities take place in retail stores in Denmark, Sweden, Norway, Finland, Poland, the Czech Republic, Austria, Hungary, Switzerland, Slovakia, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia, Serbia, the Ukraine, Rumania, Bulgaria and the USA.
Development in the financial year
Group revenue amounts to DKK 14,072,238k compared to DKK 12,717,550k in financial year 2014/15.
Profit before financial income and expenses amounts to DKK 1,069,917k compared to DKK 818,138 in 2014/15.
Profit for the year after tax amounts to DKK 1,407,888k compared to DKK 1,305,245k in 2014/15. The result is satisfying and in conjunction with management expectations.
Special risks
The Groupâs activities abroad imply that profit, cash flows and equity are affected by the development in exchange and interest rates of a number of currencies.
Knowledge resources
JYSK develops competent employees to undertake operational and management tasks in the Groupâs retail stores through specially adapted training programmes and at its own academy.
Corporate social responsibility
The statutory statement of corporate social responsibility and statement on the underrepresented gender appear on pages 31-38.
Expected development
For the year ahead, JYSK Holding A/S expects to realise a profit in line with the 2014/15 level provided that the financial markets evolve normally.
column81: In our opinion, Managementâs Review includes a true and fair account of the matters addressed in the Review.
column90:
Opinion
In our opinion, the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements give a true and fair view of the financial position of the Group and the Company at 31 August 2015 and of the results of the Group and Parent Company operations as well as the consolidated cash flows for the financial year 1 September 2014 - 31 August 2015 in accordance with the Danish Financial Statements Act.
column93: We recommend that the Annual Report be adopted at the Annual General Meeting.
column99: Managementâs Statement
column100:
Auditorâs Responsibility
Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements based on our audit. We conducted our audit in accordance with International Standards on Auditing and additional requirements in accordance with Danish audit regulation. This requires that we comply with ethical requirements and plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance whether the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements are free from material misstatement.
An audit involves performing audit procedures to obtain audit evidence about the amounts and disclosures in the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements. The audit procedures selected depend on the auditorâs judgment, including the assessment of the risks of material misstatement of the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements, whether due to fraud or error. In making those risk assessments, the auditor considers internal control relevant to the Companyâs preparation of Consolidated Financial Statements and Parent Company Financial Statements that give a true and fair view in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Companyâs internal control. An audit also includes evaluating the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of accounting estimates made by Management, as well as evaluating the overall presentation of the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements.
We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our audit opinion.
The audit has not resulted in any qualification.
column101:
Statement of Corporate Social Responsibility
As a global Group, JYSK Holding A/S is in contact with thousands of customers, employees and business partner as well as other stakeholders every day. That requires commitment.
Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) is a continuous process where new areas and methods constantly develop. Our goal is always to be up to date with the development and, therefore, dialogue and cooperation with different stakeholders are very important. We consider our dialogue with our surroundings a part of the learning process and essential to obtaining a better understanding of the complex challenges we face as a global company.
The improvement of social and environmental conditions is an ongoing process, and we believe that cooperation, dialogue and commitment are the way to go. Due to the complexity of CSR work, it is difficult to issue guarantees. However, we can guarantee that we are aware of our responsibility and are working to make a difference.
The different CSR processes interact and influence each other; however, these Financial Statements report on five overall themes
Environment and climate
Supplier management
Partnerships
Customers
Employees
JYSK Holding A/S addresses human rights through our strategic memberships/partnerships with BSCI, DIEH, Save the Children and FSC.
Figures marked with * reflect the results realised in JYSK NORDIC, which is the name of an operational enterprise (not a legal enterprise) which covers JYSK Holding A/S and Anpartsselskabet af 19/12 2014. Thus, results marked with * are allocated to the two holding companies.
JYSK NORDIC (JYSK) comprises the operation of JYSK in 19 countries, including the head office in Denmark and distribution centres in Denmark, Poland, Sweden and China.
ENVIRONMENT AND CLIMATE
At JYSK Holding A/S, we work to minimise our and our suppliers' environmental and climate impact.
Action and performance for the financial period 2014/15
ActionPerformance
FSC
JYSK is a member of FSC. The FSC label is found on a large number of JYSKâs wood products â particularly our garden furniture. FSCÂ®/â¢ stands for Forest Stewardship Council.All wooden garden furniture purchased for JYSKâs stores in the financial period are FSC certified.
TFT - The Forest Trust
JYSK was a co-founder of TFT in 1999 and remains a member together with DÃNISCHES BETTENLAGER (Anpartsselskabet af 31/8 1984). The organisation works to promote more sustainable forestry, so that the percentage of FSC certified wood sold worldwide will increase. Through our membership, we at JYSK are committed to increasing the percentage of FSC certified wood used in our product range.In the financial period, JYSK has continued the process of increasing the share of FSC certified indoor furniture.
PEFC
PEFC stands for Programme of the Endorsement of Forest Certification Schemes. The PEFC label is found on a number of JYSKâs indoor furniture.In the financial period, 37% of JYSKâs board-based furniture (measured on different item numbers) was PEFC certified. 45% of board-based furniture (measured on total number of items) purchased in the financial period was PEFC certified.
Energy reduction and optimisation
JYSK is working on a project to switch to LED fluorescent lights in its stores. All new stores will be fitted with LED. This also applies when existing stores are relocated to other buildings.In the financial period, LED has been installed in 252 existing stores/in connection with relocation of existing stores. All newly opened stores in the financial period have been fitted with LED.
In Denmark, 26 stores (including existing, relocated and newly opened stores) have switched to LED during the financial period which results in estimated annual energy savings of 1,460,406 kWh. This corresponds to the annual consumption of 231 detached houses with two adults and two children. The target is for all stores to switch to LED lights over a number of years.
Warehouse facilities
JYSK has invested in new and automated distribution centres with environmentally friendly building units. For example, the energy for heating is considerably reduced as the automated distribution centres consist of, among other things, high-bay stores which are only heated to five degrees centigrade.We plan in future to expand the distribution centre in Uldum and to establish a new distribution centre in Bulgaria.
In NÃ¤ssjÃ¶ in Sweden, JYSK is expanding its distribution centre: 75,000 new pallet places in new unheated high-bay stores. Moreover, LED lights are being installed in the new warehouses.
For the next financial period, funds have been allocated for switching the existing lighting at the distribution centres to LED lights. The process of switching to LED has been initiated at the distribution centre in Uldum.
At the distribution centre in Uldum, an automatic on/off switch is being fitted on the vacuum suction.
The expansion of the distribution centre in NÃ¤ssjÃ¶ is expected to be completed in 2016.
The process of switching to LED in Uldum is expected to be completed in the spring of 2016 and will provide estimated annual energy savings of approx 855,000 kWh.
The automatic on/off switch on the vacuum suction in Uldum will provide estimated annual energy savings of approx 81,000 kWh.
Transport
We have worked actively on packing goods more optimally on pallets, among other things, through e-learning and new technical machinery.In the period, 7.4% more m3 goods have been loaded onto the trucks in the distribution centre in Uldum and 3.3% more in the distribution centre in Radomsko compared to the last financial period. Thus, fewer trucks run from the warehouses to the stores, which provides CO2 savings.
The introduction of the newly built high-bay stores in NÃ¤ssjÃ¶ will imply a reduction of transports from remote warehouses. The process will continue in the new financial period.
In connection with the expansion of the distribution centre in NÃ¤ssjÃ¶, new high-bay stores will be put into operation on a current basis. The process began in July 2015 where the loading capacity reached 7.5%. At year end in August, the loading capacity was 21.1%.
SUPPLIER MANAGEMENT
JYSK Holding A/S has hundreds of suppliers from around the world. Teamwork with our suppliers is a fundamental element in our business, and it is thus here where we can make the biggest difference with respect to eg the environment, human rights and animal welfare. At JYSK Holding A/S, we take responsibility and we expect and demand that our supplier do the same.
Action and performance for the financial period 2014/15
ActionPerformance
Business Social Compliance Initiative (BSCI)
The BSCI is an international inspection and training system for suppliers. As a member, JYSK agrees to follow a shared Code of Conduct that contains 11 principles for running an ethical and socially responsible business. The principles are based on international conventions and, among other things, prohibit child labour, forced labour, corruption and discrimination, and set out requirements for safety, working hours and environmental protection. Together with DÃNISCHES BETTENLAGER (Anpartsselskabet af 31/8 1984), JYSK has been a member since 2006. JYSK and DÃNISCHES BETTENLAGER share a joint membership as a large number of our suppliers are the same.
In the financial period, 584 BSCI audits were performed at the suppliers of JYSK and DÃNISCHES BETTENLAGER.
In the financial period, we have moreover ourselves visited selected suppliers to ensure quality and compliance with the BSCI.
In the financial period, JYSK has trained all procurement staff in the BSCI processes.
In the financial period, JYSK has trained and sparred with suppliers as regards the BSCI.
In the financial period, JYSK has participated in BSCIâs "Capacity Building" working group and participated at the BSCI Annual Conference in Brussels.
Animal welfare
JYSK does not tolerate animal abuse. JYSK suppliers bind themselves by contract to only supply down and feathers from slaughterhouses â ie from slaughtered fowl. Inspections, trade documents and supplier visits ensure that our suppliers do not purchase down and feathers plucked from live fowl.In the next financial period, JYSK has initiated a new check round where we will check our approx ten suppliers of down and feathers over a number of years. During the period, JYSK has performed three audits in cooperation with IDFL.
In the period 2009-2012, JYSK has, in cooperation with International Down and Feather Laboratory (IDFL), performed checks with all our suppliers. No cases of plucking from live fowl were observed.
PARTNERSHIPS
The surrounding world affects our company, just as our company has an impact on the surroundings. Therefore, JYSK Holding A/S wants dialogue and cooperation which provide a good basis for fulfilling our responsibilities and meeting the challenges which we face as a global group.
Action and performance for the financial period 2014/15
ActionPerformance
Danish Ethical Trading Initiative (DIEH)
JYSK is a member of the DIEH. The DIEH is a Danish multi-stakeholder initiative. The objective is to jointly work with ethical trade and find constructive solutions to the challenges faced by Danish enterprises.In the financial period, JYSK has participated in meetings at the DIEH on a current basis, among other things two partnership meetings on social dialogue in Bangladesh.
Save the ChildrenAs a result of the partnership with Save the Children, all JYSK stores in Denmark, Norway, Sweden and Finland have raised funds for the many children affected by the strongest earthquake in 80 years which hit Nepal. In total, JYSKâs customers donated DKK 128,000 to the work of Save the Children in Nepal.
JYSK is a business partner to Save the Children in Denmark.
FSC Denmark
JYSK is a member of and cooperates with FSC Denmark which, among other things, works for the positioning and dissemination of the FSC label in Denmark.In the financial period, JYSK provided financial support to the FSC Design Award 2014 and contributed to drawing attention to the FSC label through blog posts.
In the financial period, JYSK supported the Green Goods Auction 2015 by donation tables and chairs.
CUSTOMERS
Consideration and thought for our customers constitute the cornerstones of JYSK Holding A/S. Therefore, we naturally take responsibility for the products we sell â both when it comes to use and materials.
Action and performance for the financial period 2014/15
ActionPerformance
The Oeko-Tex label The label ensures that the products are inspected for dangerous colouring agents and chemicals, and that the Oeko-Tex Standard 100 requirements have been met. We continuously work on increasing the number of products which may be certified, among other things, duvets, pillows and mattresses.
In the financial period, we have continued our work of extending the range of products which may be Oeko-Tex Standard 100 certified. The Oeko-Tex Standard 100 label is found on a large number of our products, among other things on 99% of our bed linen, sheets and towels. All textiles meet the requirements of the Oeko-tex label.
Product safety and quality
Besides tests and documentation from suppliers, we also test the products ourselves. We moreover use external testing firms and spot-checking on a current basis. JYSK has prepared an annual wheel to ensure that we cover all product groups.In the financial period, external testing firms have performed 360 tests and inspections on behalf of JYSK.
JYSK focuses on reducing the use of dangerous phthalate in our products.
JYSK has prepared a six-stage model for quality control which, among other things, comprises quality assurance with our suppliers, assembly days, quality check at reception at distribution centres and feedback from the stores.In the financial period, all vinyl tablecloths in our range have been free of dangerous phthalate.
In the financial period, we had âassembly daysâ. In the spring of 2015, a test team of JYSK employees travelled to China to assemble and test furniture for the indoor season 2015. The furniture was subsequently checked again in Poland. The purpose was to ensure that the furniture which is subsequently sold in the stores meets our quality requirements.
The CertiPUR Label
The label is a voluntary standard to promote safety, health and environmental (SHE) performance in flexible polyurethane foams used for, among other things, mattresses.In the financial period, 38% of the mattresses and top mattresses (number of items) sold by JYSK were labelled with the CertiPUR Label.
EMPLOYEES
The underrepresented gender
At JYSK Holding A/S, we want our employees to represent the demographic distribution in society, including the distribution of men and women in Management. We find this to be an advantage for both our employees and our customers.
JYSK Holding A/S is a family-owned company. We have a target ratio of at least 25% women on the Board of Directors. We have achieved our target ratio as we have four board members one of whom is a woman.
Health & safety, job satisfaction and development
At JYSK Holding A/S, we find it very important to offer our employees a safe and healthy working environment.
At JYSK Holding A/S, we focus on internal recruitment when filling executive positions. As a natural extension of this focus, we offer many opportunities for professional development and career.
Action and performance for the financial period 2014/15
ActionPerformance
The underrepresented gender
JYSK bases its work on the talent and development programme âSIRIUSâ at all levels in the organisation. The objective of SIRIUS is to assess all people â irrespective of gender, race, religion or political affiliation â as regards their ability to work in accordance with JYSK VALUES and JYSK LEADERSHIP. Potential leaders are identified and selected for four development programmes at different levels. JYSKâs top management training is called JIRA â JYSK International Retail Academy. JIRA was launched in 2012 and has since then served as the most important pipeline with respect to recruitment for top management functions in JYSK.In the financial period, the gender representation ratio in the top executive training programme, JIRA, was 54-46 for men and women, respectively.
As regards external recruitment, JYSK continuously ensures that both genders have equal opportunities for being considered for an executive position. This is, among other things, ensured through training of recruitment responsible employees.
In the financial period, approx 1000 individuals participated in training which related to recruitment.
JYSK is moreover in the process of training new trainers according to the principleâTrain the Trainerâ. In the financial period, we have held two Train the Trainer sessions with 10 participants. The 20 participants in total are now ready to train others in, among other things, recruitment.
Health & safety, job satisfaction and development
JYSK continuously strives to improve health and safety through training of the employees. For example, pallet safety â ie how to pack a pallet with products to prevent tipping.
In the financial period, absence due to sickness declined from 3.4% to 3.7%. The reason is primarily due to long-term sickness, which constitutes 1.9% of the 3.7%. An individual plan is prepared for each person on long-term sickness leave.
JYSK has focus on preventing heavy lifts by investing in machinery/new technology for stores and warehouses.In the financial period, JYSKâs distribution centre in Uldum received a prize from the Danish trade union 3F for its efforts to prevents work-related accidents and occupational injuries â eg through investing in technology.
JYSK has set a target for 80% internal recruitment. In the financial period, JYSK achieved an internal recruitment percentage of 59.
As a part of the internal career paths, JYSK applies the talent and development programme 'SIRIUS' at all levels in the organisation in order to ensure the internal pipeline.
column102:
Managementâs Responsibility for the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements
Management is responsible for the preparation of Consolidated Financial Statements and Parent Company Financial Statements that give a true and fair view in accordance with the Danish Financial Statements Act, and for such internal control as Management determines is necessary to enable the preparation of Consolidated Financial Statements and Parent Company Financial Statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error.
column103:
Statement on Managementâs Review
We have read Managementâs Review in accordance with the Danish Financial Statements Act. We have not performed any procedures additional to the audit of the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements. On this basis, in our opinion, the information provided in Managementâs Review is consistent with the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements.

column26: To the shareholders of JYSK Holding A/S
column29: The Annual Report was prepared in accordance with the Danish Financial Statements Act.
column30: In our opinion, the Parent Company Financial Statements and the Consolidated Financial Statements give a true and fair view of the financial position of the Parent Company and the Group at 31 August 2015 and of the results of the Parent Company and the Group operations and cash flows for 2014/15.
column33:
Cash Flow Statement
The cash flow statement shows the Groupâs cash flows for the year broken down by operating, investing and financing activities, changes for the year in cash and cash equivalents as well as the Groupâs cash and cash equivalents at the beginning and end of the year.
No cash flow statement has been prepared for the Parent Company as the Parent Company cash flows are included in the Consolidated Cash Flow Statement.
Cash flows from operating activities
Cash flows from operating activities are calculated as the net profit/loss for the year adjusted for changes in working capital and non-cash operating items such as depreciation, amortisation and impairment losses, and provisions. Working capital comprises current assets less short-term debt excluding items included in cash and cash equivalents.
Cash flows from investing activities
Cash flows from investing activities comprise cash flows from acquisitions and disposals of intangible assets, property, plant and equipment as well as fixed asset investments.
Cash flows from financing activities
Cash flows from financing activities comprise cash flows from the raising and repayment of long-term debt as well as payments to and from shareholders.

The cash flow statement cannot be immediately derived from the published financial records.
column34:
Derivative financial instruments
Derivative financial instruments are initially recognised in the balance sheet at cost and are subsequently remeasured at their fair values. Positive and negative fair values of derivative financial instruments are classified as other receivables and other payables, respectively.
Changes in the fair values of derivative financial instruments are recognised in the income statement together with any changes in the fair value of the hedged asset or the hedged liability.
column36:
The Annual Report for 2014/15 has been prepared in DKK.

Recognition and measurement
Revenues are recognised in the income statement as earned, including value adjustments of financial assets and liabilities. Moreover, all expenses are recognised in the income statement, including depreciation, amortisation and impairment losses.
Assets are recognised in the balance sheet when it is probable that future economic benefits attributable to the asset will flow to the Company, and the value of the asset can be measured reliably.
Liabilities are recognised in the balance sheet when it is probable that future economic benefits will flow out of the Company, and the value of the liability can be measured reliably.
Assets and liabilities are initially measured at cost. Subsequently, assets and liabilities are measured as described for each item below.
column37:
Depreciation
Depreciation comprises depreciation for the year of property, plant and equipment.
column38:
Current asset investments
Current asset investments consist of listed bonds and shares, which are measured at fair values at the balance sheet date corresponding to quoted market prices.
column39:
Investments in subsidiaries and associates
Investments in subsidiaries and associates are recognised and measured under the equity method.
The items âInvestments in subsidiariesâ and âInvestments in associatesâ in the balance sheet include the proportionate ownership share of the net asset value of the enterprises calculated on the basis of the fair values of identifiable net assets at the time of acquisition with deduction or addition of unrealised intercompany profits or losses and with addition of any remaining value of positive differences (goodwill) and deduction of any remaining value of negative differences (negative goodwill).
The total net revaluation of investments in subsidiaries and associates is transferred upon distribution of profit to "Reserve for net revaluation under the equity method" under equity. The reserve is reduced by dividend distributed to the Parent Company and adjusted for other equity movements in subsidiaries and associates.
Subsidiaries and associates with a negative net asset value are recognised at DKK 0. Any legal or constructive obligation of the Parent Company to cover the negative balance of the subsidiary and associate is recognised in provisions.
column40:
Cost of sales
Cost of sales comprises cost incurred in connection with the purchase of commercial products.
column41:
Prepayments and deferred income
Prepayments comprise expenses incurred relating to subsequent financial years. The item comprises prepaid expenses concerning rent and marketing.
Deferred income comprises payments received in respect of income in subsequent years.
column42:
Staff expenses
Staff expenses comprise wages and salaries as well as payroll related expenses.
column43:
Other external expenses
Other external expenses comprise expenses for premises, sales and distribution as well as administrative expenses, etc.
column44:
Financial income and expenses
Financial income and expenses comprise profit/loss on investments in subsidiaries and associates after tax, interest, realised and unrealised exchange adjustments, price adjustment of securities and changes to the carrying amount of financial instruments.
column45:
Intangible assets
Intangible assets are measured at cost less accumulated amortisation and less any accumulated impairment losses.
Amortisation is based on cost reduced by any residual value. Goodwill is amortised on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful life determined on the basis of Managementâs experience, which is
Goodwill7-15 years
Software3-5 years
column46:
Inventories
Inventories are measured at the lower of cost under the average cost formula and net realisable value. The net realisable value of inventories is calculated at the total of future sales revenue which the inventories are expected to generate at the balance sheet date in the process of normal operations allowing for marketability, obsolescence and development in expected selling price with deduction of selling expenses expected to be incurred to realise the sale.
The cost of goods for resale, raw materials and consumables equals landed cost.
column47:
Deposits
Deposits are recognised and measured at cost.
column48:
Financial debts
Financial debts are measured at amortised cost, substantially corresponding to nominal value.
column49:
Other operating income and expenses
Other operating income and other operating expenses comprise income and expenses of a secondary nature to the core activities of the Group, including gains and losses on current replacement of fixed assets.
column50:
Property, plant and equipment
Property, plant and equipment are measured at cost less accumulated depreciation. Cost comprises the cost of acquisition and expenses directly related to the acquisition up until the time when the asset is ready for use.
Depreciation based on cost reduced by any residual value is calculated on a straight-line basis over the expected useful lives of the assets, which are
Land and buildings25 years
Fixtures and fittings, tools and equipment3 - 10 years
Trucks and passenger cars4 - 5 years
Leasehold improvementsOver the lease period
Profits and losses from current replacement of property, plant and equipment are recognised in âOther operating incomeâ or âOther operating expensesâ.
column51:
Provisions
Provisions are recognised when - in consequence of an event occurred before or on the balance sheet date - the Company has a legal or constructive obligation and it is probable that economic benefits must be given up to settle the obligation.
Any obligation of the Parent Company to cover negative balances of the subsidiaries is recognised in provisions.
column52:
Receivables
Receivables are recognised in the balance sheet at the lower of amortised cost and net realisable value, which generally corresponds to nominal value less provisions for bad debts.
Provisions for bad debts are determined on the basis of an individual assessment of each receivable, and in respect of trade receivables, a general provision is also made based on the Companyâs experience.
column53:
Revenue
Revenue from the sale of goods for resale is recognised in the income statement if delivery and transfer of risk have been made before year end. Revenue is recognised exclusive of VAT and net of discounts relating to sales.
column54:
Corporation tax and deferred tax
The Company is jointly taxed with Danish subsidiaries. The tax effect of the joint taxation with the subsidiaries is allocated to Danish enterprises showing profits or losses in proportion to their taxable incomes (full allocation with credit for tax losses). The jointly taxed enterprises have adopted the on-account taxation scheme.
Tax for the year consists of current tax for the year and deferred tax for the year. The tax attributable to the profit for the year is recognised in the income statement.
Current tax liabilities are recognised as payables in the balance sheet.
Deferred tax is measured using the balance sheet liability method in respect of all temporary differences arising between the tax bases of assets and liabilities and their carrying amounts for financial reporting purposes. Deferred tax is measured on the basis of the tax rules and tax rates that will be effective under the legislation at the balance sheet date when the deferred tax is expected to crystallise as current tax.
column55:
Financial Highlights
Ratios are calculated as follows
Return on assets =
Profit before financials x 100
Total assets
Solvency ratio =
Equity at year end x 100
Total assets
Return on equity =
Net profit for the year x 100
Average equity
column56:
Translation policies
Transactions in foreign currencies are translated at the exchange rates at the dates of transaction. Gains and losses arising due to differences between the transaction date rates and the rates at the dates of payment are recognised in financial income and expenses in the income statement.
Receivables, payables and other monetary items in foreign currencies that have not been settled at the balance sheet date are translated at the exchange rates at the balance sheet date. Any differences between the exchange rates at the balance sheet date and the transaction date rates are recognised in financial income and expenses in the income statement.
column57: The accounting policies applied remain unchanged from last year; however, a few reclassifications of comparative figures have been made.

column65:
Cash and cash equivalents
Cash and cash equivalents comprise "Cash at bank and in hand" and "Current asset investments" as well as âCredit institutionsâ under liabilities and equity. "Current asset investments" consist of short-term securities with an insignificant risk of value changes that can readily be turned into cash.
column71: The Board of Directors and the Executive Board have today considered and adopted the Annual Report of JYSK Holding A/S for the financial year 1 September 2014 â 31 August 2015.
column72:
Report on the Consolidated Financial Statements and Parent Company Financial Statements
We have audited the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements of JYSK Holding A/S for the financial year 1 September 2014 to 31 August 2015, which comprise income statement, balance sheet, notes and accounting policies for both the Group and the Parent Company, as well as consolidated cash flow statement. The Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements are prepared in accordance with the Danish Financial Statements Act.
column73: Independent Auditorâs Report
column74:
JYSK Holding A/S is described by the following financial highlights

The ratios have been prepared in accordance with the definitions provided under accounting policies.
column75:
Basis of consolidation
The Consolidated Financial Statements comprise the Parent Company, JYSK Holding A/S, and subsidiaries in which the Parent Company directly or indirectly holds more than 50% of the votes or in which the Parent Company, through share ownership or otherwise, exercises control. Enterprises in which the Group holds between 20% and 50% of the votes and exercises significant influence but not control are classified as associates.
Elimination is made of intercompany income and expenses, shareholdings, dividends and accounts as well as of realised and unrealised profits and losses on transactions between the consolidated enterprises.
The financial statements applied for the Groupâs Annual Report have been prepared in accordance with the accounting policies of the Group.
column76:
Non-controlling interests
On statement of group results and group equity, the shares of results and equity of subsidiaries attributable to minority interests are recognised as separate items in the income statement and the balance sheet.
column77: The Annual Report of JYSK Holding A/S for the financial year 1 September 2014 to 31 August 2015 has been prepared in accordance with the provisions of the Danish Financial Statements Act applying to large enterprises of reporting class C.
column78:
Segment reporting
In accordance with section 96(1) of the Danish Financial Statements Act, disclosures on revenue broken down by business segments are not provided as the Companyâs Executive Board and Board of Directors assess that such disclosures would be very detrimental to the Company.
column80:
Managementâs Review
Main activity
The activity of the Parent Company comprises operation of real property, investments in subsidiaries and associates as well as current asset investments.
The Groupâs main activities are carried out in subsidiaries dealing in retail trade through the retail chain JYSK selling everything for the bed room, bath room, other rooms, the window and the patio. The activities take place in retail stores in Denmark, Sweden, Norway, Finland, Poland, the Czech Republic, Austria, Hungary, Switzerland, Slovakia, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia, Serbia, the Ukraine, Rumania, Bulgaria and the USA.
Development in the financial year
Group revenue amounts to DKK 14,072,238k compared to DKK 12,717,550k in financial year 2014/15.
Profit before financial income and expenses amounts to DKK 1,069,917k compared to DKK 818,138 in 2014/15.
Profit for the year after tax amounts to DKK 1,407,888k compared to DKK 1,305,245k in 2014/15. The result is satisfying and in conjunction with management expectations.
Special risks
The Groupâs activities abroad imply that profit, cash flows and equity are affected by the development in exchange and interest rates of a number of currencies.
Knowledge resources
JYSK develops competent employees to undertake operational and management tasks in the Groupâs retail stores through specially adapted training programmes and at its own academy.
Corporate social responsibility
The statutory statement of corporate social responsibility and statement on the underrepresented gender appear on pages 31-38.
Expected development
For the year ahead, JYSK Holding A/S expects to realise a profit in line with the 2014/15 level provided that the financial markets evolve normally.
column81: In our opinion, Managementâs Review includes a true and fair account of the matters addressed in the Review.
column90:
Opinion
In our opinion, the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements give a true and fair view of the financial position of the Group and the Company at 31 August 2015 and of the results of the Group and Parent Company operations as well as the consolidated cash flows for the financial year 1 September 2014 - 31 August 2015 in accordance with the Danish Financial Statements Act.
column93: We recommend that the Annual Report be adopted at the Annual General Meeting.
column99: Managementâs Statement
column100:
Auditorâs Responsibility
Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements based on our audit. We conducted our audit in accordance with International Standards on Auditing and additional requirements in accordance with Danish audit regulation. This requires that we comply with ethical requirements and plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance whether the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements are free from material misstatement.
An audit involves performing audit procedures to obtain audit evidence about the amounts and disclosures in the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements. The audit procedures selected depend on the auditorâs judgment, including the assessment of the risks of material misstatement of the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements, whether due to fraud or error. In making those risk assessments, the auditor considers internal control relevant to the Companyâs preparation of Consolidated Financial Statements and Parent Company Financial Statements that give a true and fair view in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Companyâs internal control. An audit also includes evaluating the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of accounting estimates made by Management, as well as evaluating the overall presentation of the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements.
We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our audit opinion.
The audit has not resulted in any qualification.
column101:
Statement of Corporate Social Responsibility
As a global Group, JYSK Holding A/S is in contact with thousands of customers, employees and business partner as well as other stakeholders every day. That requires commitment.
Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) is a continuous process where new areas and methods constantly develop. Our goal is always to be up to date with the development and, therefore, dialogue and cooperation with different stakeholders are very important. We consider our dialogue with our surroundings a part of the learning process and essential to obtaining a better understanding of the complex challenges we face as a global company.
The improvement of social and environmental conditions is an ongoing process, and we believe that cooperation, dialogue and commitment are the way to go. Due to the complexity of CSR work, it is difficult to issue guarantees. However, we can guarantee that we are aware of our responsibility and are working to make a difference.
The different CSR processes interact and influence each other; however, these Financial Statements report on five overall themes
Environment and climate
Supplier management
Partnerships
Customers
Employees
JYSK Holding A/S addresses human rights through our strategic memberships/partnerships with BSCI, DIEH, Save the Children and FSC.
Figures marked with * reflect the results realised in JYSK NORDIC, which is the name of an operational enterprise (not a legal enterprise) which covers JYSK Holding A/S and Anpartsselskabet af 19/12 2014. Thus, results marked with * are allocated to the two holding companies.
JYSK NORDIC (JYSK) comprises the operation of JYSK in 19 countries, including the head office in Denmark and distribution centres in Denmark, Poland, Sweden and China.
ENVIRONMENT AND CLIMATE
At JYSK Holding A/S, we work to minimise our and our suppliers' environmental and climate impact.
Action and performance for the financial period 2014/15
ActionPerformance
FSC
JYSK is a member of FSC. The FSC label is found on a large number of JYSKâs wood products â particularly our garden furniture. FSCÂ®/â¢ stands for Forest Stewardship Council.All wooden garden furniture purchased for JYSKâs stores in the financial period are FSC certified.
TFT - The Forest Trust
JYSK was a co-founder of TFT in 1999 and remains a member together with DÃNISCHES BETTENLAGER (Anpartsselskabet af 31/8 1984). The organisation works to promote more sustainable forestry, so that the percentage of FSC certified wood sold worldwide will increase. Through our membership, we at JYSK are committed to increasing the percentage of FSC certified wood used in our product range.In the financial period, JYSK has continued the process of increasing the share of FSC certified indoor furniture.
PEFC
PEFC stands for Programme of the Endorsement of Forest Certification Schemes. The PEFC label is found on a number of JYSKâs indoor furniture.In the financial period, 37% of JYSKâs board-based furniture (measured on different item numbers) was PEFC certified. 45% of board-based furniture (measured on total number of items) purchased in the financial period was PEFC certified.
Energy reduction and optimisation
JYSK is working on a project to switch to LED fluorescent lights in its stores. All new stores will be fitted with LED. This also applies when existing stores are relocated to other buildings.In the financial period, LED has been installed in 252 existing stores/in connection with relocation of existing stores. All newly opened stores in the financial period have been fitted with LED.
In Denmark, 26 stores (including existing, relocated and newly opened stores) have switched to LED during the financial period which results in estimated annual energy savings of 1,460,406 kWh. This corresponds to the annual consumption of 231 detached houses with two adults and two children. The target is for all stores to switch to LED lights over a number of years.
Warehouse facilities
JYSK has invested in new and automated distribution centres with environmentally friendly building units. For example, the energy for heating is considerably reduced as the automated distribution centres consist of, among other things, high-bay stores which are only heated to five degrees centigrade.We plan in future to expand the distribution centre in Uldum and to establish a new distribution centre in Bulgaria.
In NÃ¤ssjÃ¶ in Sweden, JYSK is expanding its distribution centre: 75,000 new pallet places in new unheated high-bay stores. Moreover, LED lights are being installed in the new warehouses.
For the next financial period, funds have been allocated for switching the existing lighting at the distribution centres to LED lights. The process of switching to LED has been initiated at the distribution centre in Uldum.
At the distribution centre in Uldum, an automatic on/off switch is being fitted on the vacuum suction.
The expansion of the distribution centre in NÃ¤ssjÃ¶ is expected to be completed in 2016.
The process of switching to LED in Uldum is expected to be completed in the spring of 2016 and will provide estimated annual energy savings of approx 855,000 kWh.
The automatic on/off switch on the vacuum suction in Uldum will provide estimated annual energy savings of approx 81,000 kWh.
Transport
We have worked actively on packing goods more optimally on pallets, among other things, through e-learning and new technical machinery.In the period, 7.4% more m3 goods have been loaded onto the trucks in the distribution centre in Uldum and 3.3% more in the distribution centre in Radomsko compared to the last financial period. Thus, fewer trucks run from the warehouses to the stores, which provides CO2 savings.
The introduction of the newly built high-bay stores in NÃ¤ssjÃ¶ will imply a reduction of transports from remote warehouses. The process will continue in the new financial period.
In connection with the expansion of the distribution centre in NÃ¤ssjÃ¶, new high-bay stores will be put into operation on a current basis. The process began in July 2015 where the loading capacity reached 7.5%. At year end in August, the loading capacity was 21.1%.
SUPPLIER MANAGEMENT
JYSK Holding A/S has hundreds of suppliers from around the world. Teamwork with our suppliers is a fundamental element in our business, and it is thus here where we can make the biggest difference with respect to eg the environment, human rights and animal welfare. At JYSK Holding A/S, we take responsibility and we expect and demand that our supplier do the same.
Action and performance for the financial period 2014/15
ActionPerformance
Business Social Compliance Initiative (BSCI)
The BSCI is an international inspection and training system for suppliers. As a member, JYSK agrees to follow a shared Code of Conduct that contains 11 principles for running an ethical and socially responsible business. The principles are based on international conventions and, among other things, prohibit child labour, forced labour, corruption and discrimination, and set out requirements for safety, working hours and environmental protection. Together with DÃNISCHES BETTENLAGER (Anpartsselskabet af 31/8 1984), JYSK has been a member since 2006. JYSK and DÃNISCHES BETTENLAGER share a joint membership as a large number of our suppliers are the same.
In the financial period, 584 BSCI audits were performed at the suppliers of JYSK and DÃNISCHES BETTENLAGER.
In the financial period, we have moreover ourselves visited selected suppliers to ensure quality and compliance with the BSCI.
In the financial period, JYSK has trained all procurement staff in the BSCI processes.
In the financial period, JYSK has trained and sparred with suppliers as regards the BSCI.
In the financial period, JYSK has participated in BSCIâs "Capacity Building" working group and participated at the BSCI Annual Conference in Brussels.
Animal welfare
JYSK does not tolerate animal abuse. JYSK suppliers bind themselves by contract to only supply down and feathers from slaughterhouses â ie from slaughtered fowl. Inspections, trade documents and supplier visits ensure that our suppliers do not purchase down and feathers plucked from live fowl.In the next financial period, JYSK has initiated a new check round where we will check our approx ten suppliers of down and feathers over a number of years. During the period, JYSK has performed three audits in cooperation with IDFL.
In the period 2009-2012, JYSK has, in cooperation with International Down and Feather Laboratory (IDFL), performed checks with all our suppliers. No cases of plucking from live fowl were observed.
PARTNERSHIPS
The surrounding world affects our company, just as our company has an impact on the surroundings. Therefore, JYSK Holding A/S wants dialogue and cooperation which provide a good basis for fulfilling our responsibilities and meeting the challenges which we face as a global group.
Action and performance for the financial period 2014/15
ActionPerformance
Danish Ethical Trading Initiative (DIEH)
JYSK is a member of the DIEH. The DIEH is a Danish multi-stakeholder initiative. The objective is to jointly work with ethical trade and find constructive solutions to the challenges faced by Danish enterprises.In the financial period, JYSK has participated in meetings at the DIEH on a current basis, among other things two partnership meetings on social dialogue in Bangladesh.
Save the ChildrenAs a result of the partnership with Save the Children, all JYSK stores in Denmark, Norway, Sweden and Finland have raised funds for the many children affected by the strongest earthquake in 80 years which hit Nepal. In total, JYSKâs customers donated DKK 128,000 to the work of Save the Children in Nepal.
JYSK is a business partner to Save the Children in Denmark.
FSC Denmark
JYSK is a member of and cooperates with FSC Denmark which, among other things, works for the positioning and dissemination of the FSC label in Denmark.In the financial period, JYSK provided financial support to the FSC Design Award 2014 and contributed to drawing attention to the FSC label through blog posts.
In the financial period, JYSK supported the Green Goods Auction 2015 by donation tables and chairs.
CUSTOMERS
Consideration and thought for our customers constitute the cornerstones of JYSK Holding A/S. Therefore, we naturally take responsibility for the products we sell â both when it comes to use and materials.
Action and performance for the financial period 2014/15
ActionPerformance
The Oeko-Tex label The label ensures that the products are inspected for dangerous colouring agents and chemicals, and that the Oeko-Tex Standard 100 requirements have been met. We continuously work on increasing the number of products which may be certified, among other things, duvets, pillows and mattresses.
In the financial period, we have continued our work of extending the range of products which may be Oeko-Tex Standard 100 certified. The Oeko-Tex Standard 100 label is found on a large number of our products, among other things on 99% of our bed linen, sheets and towels. All textiles meet the requirements of the Oeko-tex label.
Product safety and quality
Besides tests and documentation from suppliers, we also test the products ourselves. We moreover use external testing firms and spot-checking on a current basis. JYSK has prepared an annual wheel to ensure that we cover all product groups.In the financial period, external testing firms have performed 360 tests and inspections on behalf of JYSK.
JYSK focuses on reducing the use of dangerous phthalate in our products.
JYSK has prepared a six-stage model for quality control which, among other things, comprises quality assurance with our suppliers, assembly days, quality check at reception at distribution centres and feedback from the stores.In the financial period, all vinyl tablecloths in our range have been free of dangerous phthalate.
In the financial period, we had âassembly daysâ. In the spring of 2015, a test team of JYSK employees travelled to China to assemble and test furniture for the indoor season 2015. The furniture was subsequently checked again in Poland. The purpose was to ensure that the furniture which is subsequently sold in the stores meets our quality requirements.
The CertiPUR Label
The label is a voluntary standard to promote safety, health and environmental (SHE) performance in flexible polyurethane foams used for, among other things, mattresses.In the financial period, 38% of the mattresses and top mattresses (number of items) sold by JYSK were labelled with the CertiPUR Label.
EMPLOYEES
The underrepresented gender
At JYSK Holding A/S, we want our employees to represent the demographic distribution in society, including the distribution of men and women in Management. We find this to be an advantage for both our employees and our customers.
JYSK Holding A/S is a family-owned company. We have a target ratio of at least 25% women on the Board of Directors. We have achieved our target ratio as we have four board members one of whom is a woman.
Health & safety, job satisfaction and development
At JYSK Holding A/S, we find it very important to offer our employees a safe and healthy working environment.
At JYSK Holding A/S, we focus on internal recruitment when filling executive positions. As a natural extension of this focus, we offer many opportunities for professional development and career.
Action and performance for the financial period 2014/15
ActionPerformance
The underrepresented gender
JYSK bases its work on the talent and development programme âSIRIUSâ at all levels in the organisation. The objective of SIRIUS is to assess all people â irrespective of gender, race, religion or political affiliation â as regards their ability to work in accordance with JYSK VALUES and JYSK LEADERSHIP. Potential leaders are identified and selected for four development programmes at different levels. JYSKâs top management training is called JIRA â JYSK International Retail Academy. JIRA was launched in 2012 and has since then served as the most important pipeline with respect to recruitment for top management functions in JYSK.In the financial period, the gender representation ratio in the top executive training programme, JIRA, was 54-46 for men and women, respectively.
As regards external recruitment, JYSK continuously ensures that both genders have equal opportunities for being considered for an executive position. This is, among other things, ensured through training of recruitment responsible employees.
In the financial period, approx 1000 individuals participated in training which related to recruitment.
JYSK is moreover in the process of training new trainers according to the principleâTrain the Trainerâ. In the financial period, we have held two Train the Trainer sessions with 10 participants. The 20 participants in total are now ready to train others in, among other things, recruitment.
Health & safety, job satisfaction and development
JYSK continuously strives to improve health and safety through training of the employees. For example, pallet safety â ie how to pack a pallet with products to prevent tipping.
In the financial period, absence due to sickness declined from 3.4% to 3.7%. The reason is primarily due to long-term sickness, which constitutes 1.9% of the 3.7%. An individual plan is prepared for each person on long-term sickness leave.
JYSK has focus on preventing heavy lifts by investing in machinery/new technology for stores and warehouses.In the financial period, JYSKâs distribution centre in Uldum received a prize from the Danish trade union 3F for its efforts to prevents work-related accidents and occupational injuries â eg through investing in technology.
JYSK has set a target for 80% internal recruitment. In the financial period, JYSK achieved an internal recruitment percentage of 59.
As a part of the internal career paths, JYSK applies the talent and development programme 'SIRIUS' at all levels in the organisation in order to ensure the internal pipeline.
column102:
Managementâs Responsibility for the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements
Management is responsible for the preparation of Consolidated Financial Statements and Parent Company Financial Statements that give a true and fair view in accordance with the Danish Financial Statements Act, and for such internal control as Management determines is necessary to enable the preparation of Consolidated Financial Statements and Parent Company Financial Statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error.
column103:
Statement on Managementâs Review
We have read Managementâs Review in accordance with the Danish Financial Statements Act. We have not performed any procedures additional to the audit of the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements. On this basis, in our opinion, the information provided in Managementâs Review is consistent with the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Parent Company Financial Statements.

column26: To the shareholders of JYSK Holding A/S
column29: The Annual Report was prepared in accordance with the Danish Financial Statements Act.
column30: In our opinion, the Parent Company Financial Statements and the Consolidated Financial Statements give a true and fair view of the financial position of the Parent Company and the Group at 31 August 2015 and of the results of the Parent Company and the Group operations and cash flows for 2014/15.
column33:
Cash Flow Statement
The cash flow statement shows the Groupâs cash flows for the year broken down by operating, investing and financing activities, changes for the year in cash and cash equivalents as well as the Groupâs cash and cash equivalents at the beginning and end of the year.
No cash flow statement has been prepared for the Parent Company as the Parent Company cash flows are included in the Consolidated Cash Flow Statement.
Cash flows from operating activities
Cash flows from operating activities are calculated as the net profit/loss for the year adjusted for changes in working capital and non-cash operating items such as depreciation, amortisation and impairment losses, and provisions. Working capital comprises current assets less short-term debt excluding items included in cash and cash equivalents.
Cash flows from investing activities
Cash flows from investing activities comprise cash flows from acquisitions and disposals of intangible assets, property, plant and equipment as well as fixed asset investments.
Cash flows from financing activities
Cash flows from financing activities comprise cash flows from the raising and repayment of long-term debt as well as payments to and from shareholders.

The cash flow statement cannot be immediately derived from the published financial records.
column34:
Derivative financial instruments
Derivative financial instruments are initially recognised in the balance sheet at cost and are subsequently remeasured at their fair values. Positive and negative fair values of derivative financial instruments are classified as other receivables and other payables, respectively.
Changes in the fair values of derivative financial instruments are recognised in the income statement together with any changes in the fair value of the hedged asset or the hedged liability.
column36:
The Annual Report for 2014/15 has been prepared in DKK.

Recognition and measurement
Revenues are recognised in the income statement as earned, including value adjustments of financial assets and liabilities. Moreover, all expenses are recognised in the income statement, including depreciation, amortisation and impairment losses.
Assets are recognised in the balance sheet when it is probable that future economic benefits attributable to the asset will flow to the Company, and the value of the asset can be measured reliably.
Liabilities are recognised in the balance sheet when it is probable that future economic benefits will flow out of the Company, and the value of the liability can be measured reliably.
Assets and liabilities are initially measured at cost. Subsequently, assets and liabilities are measured as described for each item below.
column37:
Depreciation
Depreciation comprises depreciation for the year of property, plant and equipment.
column38:
Current asset investments
Current asset investments consist of listed bonds and shares, which are measured at fair values at the balance sheet date corresponding to quoted market prices.
column39:
Investments in subsidiaries and associates
Investments in subsidiaries and associates are recognised and measured under the equity method.
The items âInvestments in subsidiariesâ and âInvestments in associatesâ in the balance sheet include the proportionate ownership share of the net asset value of the enterprises calculated on the basis of the fair values of identifiable net assets at the time of acquisition with deduction or addition of unrealised intercompany profits or losses and with addition of any remaining value of positive differences (goodwill) and deduction of any remaining value of negative differences (negative goodwill).
The total net revaluation of investments in subsidiaries and associates is transferred upon distribution of profit to "Reserve for net revaluation under the equity method" under equity. The reserve is reduced by dividend distributed to the Parent Company and adjusted for other equity movements in subsidiaries and associates.
Subsidiaries and associates with a negative net asset value are recognised at DKK 0. Any legal or constructive obligation of the Parent Company to cover the negative balance of the subsidiary and associate is recognised in provisions.
column40:
Cost of sales
Cost of sales comprises cost incurred in connection with the purchase of commercial products.
column41:
Prepayments and deferred income
Prepayments comprise expenses incurred relating to subsequent financial years. The item comprises prepaid expenses concerning rent and marketing.
Deferred income comprises payments received in respect of income in subsequent years.
column42:
Staff expenses
Staff expenses comprise wages and salaries as well as payroll related expenses.
column43:
Other external expenses
Other external expenses comprise expenses for premises, sales and distribution as well as administrative expenses, etc.
column44:
Financial income and expenses
Financial income and expenses comprise profit/loss on investments in subsidiaries and associates after tax, interest, realised and unrealised exchange adjustments, price adjustment of securities and changes to the carrying amount of financial instruments.
column45:
Intangible assets
Intangible assets are measured at cost less accumulated amortisation and less any accumulated impairment losses.
Amortisation is based on cost reduced by any residual value. Goodwill is amortised on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful life determined on the basis of Managementâs experience, which is
Goodwill7-15 years
Software3-5 years
column46:
Inventories
Inventories are measured at the lower of cost under the average cost formula and net realisable value. The net realisable value of inventories is calculated at the total of future sales revenue which the inventories are expected to generate at the balance sheet date in the process of normal operations allowing for marketability, obsolescence and development in expected selling price with deduction of selling expenses expected to be incurred to realise the sale.
The cost of goods for resale, raw materials and consumables equals landed cost.
column47:
Deposits
Deposits are recognised and measured at cost.
column48:
Financial debts
Financial debts are measured at amortised cost, substantially corresponding to nominal value.
column49:
Other operating income and expenses
Other operating income and other operating expenses comprise income and expenses of a secondary nature to the core activities of the Group, including gains and losses on current replacement of fixed assets.
column50:
Property, plant and equipment
Property, plant and equipment are measured at cost less accumulated depreciation. Cost comprises the cost of acquisition and expenses directly related to the acquisition up until the time when the asset is ready for use.
Depreciation based on cost reduced by any residual value is calculated on a straight-line basis over the expected useful lives of the assets, which are
Land and buildings25 years
Fixtures and fittings, tools and equipment3 - 10 years
Trucks and passenger cars4 - 5 years
Leasehold improvementsOver the lease period
Profits and losses from current replacement of property, plant and equipment are recognised in âOther operating incomeâ or âOther operating expensesâ.
column51:
Provisions
Provisions are recognised when - in consequence of an event occurred before or on the balance sheet date - the Company has a legal or constructive obligation and it is probable that economic benefits must be given up to settle the obligation.
Any obligation of the Parent Company to cover negative balances of the subsidiaries is recognised in provisions.
column52:
Receivables
Receivables are recognised in the balance sheet at the lower of amortised cost and net realisable value, which generally corresponds to nominal value less provisions for bad debts.
Provisions for bad debts are determined on the basis of an individual assessment of each receivable, and in respect of trade receivables, a general provision is also made based on the Companyâs experience.
column53:
Revenue
Revenue from the sale of goods for resale is recognised in the income statement if delivery and transfer of risk have been made before year end. Revenue is recognised exclusive of VAT and net of discounts relating to sales.
column54:
Corporation tax and deferred tax
The Company is jointly taxed with Danish subsidiaries. The tax effect of the joint taxation with the subsidiaries is allocated to Danish enterprises showing profits or losses in proportion to their taxable incomes (full allocation with credit for tax losses). The jointly taxed enterprises have adopted the on-account taxation scheme.
Tax for the year consists of current tax for the year and deferred tax for the year. The tax attributable to the profit for the year is recognised in the income statement.
Current tax liabilities are recognised as payables in the balance sheet.
Deferred tax is measured using the balance sheet liability method in respect of all temporary differences arising between the tax bases of assets and liabilities and their carrying amounts for financial reporting purposes. Deferred tax is measured on the basis of the tax rules and tax rates that will be effective under the legislation at the balance sheet date when the deferred tax is expected to crystallise as current tax.
column55:
Financial Highlights
Ratios are calculated as follows
Return on assets =
Profit before financials x 100
Total assets
Solvency ratio =
Equity at year end x 100
Total assets
Return on equity =
Net profit for the year x 100
Average equity
column56:
Translation policies
Transactions in foreign currencies are translated at the exchange rates at the dates of transaction. Gains and losses arising due to differences between the transaction date rates and the rates at the dates of payment are recognised in financial income and expenses in the income statement.
Receivables, payables and other monetary items in foreign currencies that have not been settled at the balance sheet date are translated at the exchange rates at the balance sheet date. Any differences between the exchange rates at the balance sheet date and the transaction date rates are recognised in financial income and expenses in the income statement.
column57: The accounting policies applied remain unchanged from last year; however, a few reclassifications of comparative figures have been made.
